Somerville|work=BostonGlobe.com}}</ref> known professionally as '''EmiSunshine''', is an American singer-songwriter from [[Madisonville, Tennessee]], and a [[Internet celebrity|social media personality]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/the-10-year-old-ukulele-playing-wunderkind-is-the-real-deal-says-marty-stuart/Content?oid=4952796|title=Ten-year-old name="today.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/video/today/54806485|title=Emily Sunshine Hamilton, 9, sings blues on TODAY|work=TODAY.com}}</ref> Her performance of [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]]' "[[Blue yodel|Blue Yodel No. 6]]" was posted on [[YouTube]] in 2014 and received over 1 million views and attention from the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'' show ([[NBC Studios (New York City)|NBC]]) and [[Music Row]].<ref name="today.com"/><ref name="Tennessean.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/12/11/emi-sunshine-sings-like-old-soul-sparkles-stage-age/20281257/|title=Emi Sunshine sings like old soul, sparkles at age 10|date=December 11, 2014|work=The Tennessean}}</ref> Her YouTube series, ''Americana Corner'', featured [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]] for its debut episode and earned a feature story in ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'s}} country section.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/see-holly-williams-perform-hank-classic-with-11-year-old-prodigy-20150625|title=See Holly Williams Perform Hank Classic With 11-Year-Old Prodigy|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=25 June 2015 }}</ref>

EmiSunshine's music is generally described as [[Country music|country]], but also exhibits [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[blues]] and [[Gospel music|gospel]] influences. She has described her style as "old-time music turned upside-down."<ref name="guitargirlmag.com">{{cite web|url=https://guitargirlmag.com/interviews/emisunshine-cma-fest-old-school-music-turned-upside-down/|title=EmiSunshine at CMA Fest: old school music turned upside down|work=GuitarGirlMag.com|date=8 July 2018 }}</ref> She is known for writing and performing songs about mature subjects not ordinarily associated with artists her age, including [[murder]], [[Poverty in the United States|poverty]], [[Politics of the United States|politics]], [[autism]] and [[family dysfunction]]. In 2017, ''Rolling Stone'' named her among "10 new country artists you need to know."<ref name="RollingStone.com">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-september-2017-199288/emisunshine-111280/|title=10 new country artists you need to know|date=September 12, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>

==Early life==
EmiSunshine was born on June 8, 2004, in [[Madisonville, Tennessee]], to Randall Hamilton, a musician and recording engineer, and Alisha Karol Hamilton, a songwriter and nurse. Randall and Alisha have said that, even as a baby, EmiSunshine exhibited a remarkable musical ability, humming along to songs with perfect pitch. "I noticed it at nine months," Randall told the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. "There was a pure tone in the key of C coming out of her. I thought, 'This baby is something. She may be able to sing when she is older.'" By the age of three, she was singing with her grandmothers. Her first performance in front of an audience occurred at age four, when she performed "[[You Are My Sunshine]]" at the wedding of her aunt and uncle.<ref name="ChicagoTribune.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-emi-sunshine-gran-old-opry-20150813-story.html|title=EmiSunshine is all country, all the time, at age 11|date=August 13, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>

EmiSunshine began singing in churches and festivals throughout East Tennessee. At the age of seven she simultaneously recorded her first two albums, ''Strong as the Tall Pine'' and ''Wide River to Cross'' in her father's studio with help from her father and her grandfather, "PaPaw Bill".<ref name="tennessean.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/12/11/emi-sunshine-sings-like-old-soul-sparkles-stage-age/20281257/|title=EmiSunshine sings like old soul, sparkles at age 10|date=December 11, 2014|work=The Tennessean}}</ref>

==Career==
===2013–2015: Breakthrough===
When EmiSunshine was nine years old, a fan in her hometown posted a video on YouTube of her singing the [[Jimmie Rodgers (pop singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] and [[Louis Armstrong]] song "Blue Yodel No. 6" at a flea market. The video went viral, attracting millions of views. As a result, she was invited to perform on NBC's [[Today (U.S. TV program)|''Today'']] show. Video of her televised performance attracted even more attention on the Internet and among country music professionals in Nashville.<ref name="NewJerseyStage.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.newjerseystage.com/articles/2018/03/22/an-interview-with-emisunshine/|title=An Interview with EmiSunshine|date=March 22, 2018|work=New Jersey Stage}}</ref>

Soon, she was writing songs and appearing on stage with established artists. In 2014, she made her debut performance at the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. She released her first single, "Oh Mary, Where Is Your Baby?" in 2014 and a year later released her next single, "I Am Able." She released the full-length album ''Black Sunday '35'' when she was nine years old. 
Also during this time, she opened for Willie Nelson in Southern California and Las Vegas, Tanya Tucker and Loretta Lynn in Branson.

===2016–present: Continued success===
In 2016, at age 12, EmiSunshine appeared in ''[[The King (2017 American film)|The King]]'', a documentary film about [[Elvis Presley]], which featured celebrities such as [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Alec Baldwin]], [[Ashton Kutcher]] and others.<ref name="Columbus Ledger-Enquirer">{{cite web|url=https://www.ledger-enquirer.com/entertainment/local-events/article228956464.html|title=Tennessee girl in viral YouTube video is now grown-up star you can see in concert|date=April 8, 2019|work=Columbus Ledger-Enquirer}}</ref> In the movie, she sang two songs she had previously written, “Danny Ray" and "Johnny June and Jesus," which she performed while riding in the backseat of Elvis Presley's 1963 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud. She later performed at the film's international premiere at the 2017 [[Cannes Film Festival]]. The soundtrack was nominated for a [[Grammy]] award.<ref name="Variety.com">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/grammy-nominations-2019-complete-list-1203082934/|title=Grammy Awards Nominations: The Complete List|date=December 7, 2018|work=Variety}}</ref>

She released her fourth studio album, ''Ragged Dreams'', in 2017, which included her two songs from ''The King''. She also attracted attention for another song on that album, "90 Miles", which was about [[autism]]. "I have a really good friend who has autism, and he was treated really differently because of it and it really bothered me," she told the ''[[South Bend Tribune]]''. "I met him and I didn't know that he had autism. The kids would tell me not to talk to him, even adults… I want this song to be something that just kind of shows people that, hey, they’re just like us."<ref name="southbendtribune.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/entertainment/inthebend/music/emisunshine-brings-fresh-face-to-country-music/article_b692f027-309e-54e3-a099-e9caee446b47.html|title=EmiSunshine brings fresh face to country music|date=April 22, 2018|work=South Bend Tribune}}</ref>

She began working with four-time Grammy-winning producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] in 2017, after she was introduced to him by her manager, Steve Pritchard.<ref name="lula1892.com">{{cite web|url=http://lula1892.com/elvis-strait-to-jesus/|title=Elvis, Strait To Jesus: Tony Brown On His Life In The Music Industry And His Brand New Book|date=June 6, 2018|work=Lula 1892}}</ref>  Emi and Brown co-produced her sixth studio album, ''Family Wars'', which was released in 2019. The album includes a duet with singer-songwriter [[Jim Lauderdale]], back up singing on one song by The McCrary Sisters and creative collaborations with other prominent musical artists in Nashville including songwriters [[Vicky McGehee]], [[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]], [[Chelle Rose]], Autumn McEntire and Fish Fisher. In a review, the music magazine ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'' wrote that the album "establishes EmiSunshine as a strong creative force… She's just plain good, with talents outliving the novelty that went along with her earliest exposure at age 9 and establishing her as someone bold and talented enough to tackle today’s issues while honoring yesterday’s folk traditions."<ref name="nodepression.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/15-year-old-emisunshine-balances-darkness-and-light-on-family-wars/|title=15-Year-Old EmiSunshine Balances Darkness and Light on 'Family Wars'|date=October 17, 2019|work=No Depression}}</ref>

On December 11, 2019, she received The [[ASCAP Foundation]] [[Desmond Child]] Anthem Award in New York City.<ref name="musicrow.com">{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/11/emisunshine-to-receive-ascap-foundation-desmond-child-anthem-award-in-new-york/|title=EmiSunshine to receive ASCAP Foundation Desmond Child Anthem Award in New York|date=November 6, 2019|work=Music Row}}</ref> The award was established by [[ASCAP]] Board member, composer and producer Desmond Child to recognize promising young artists. Child called EmiSunshine "one of the most talented up-and-coming artists and songwriters I've ever heard in AMERICAN music."<ref name="AllAccess.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/15-year-old-emisunshine-balances-darkness-and-light-on-family-wars/|title=ASCAP Foundation Honors EmiSunshine with Desmond Child Anthem Award|date=October 17, 2019|work=No Depression}}</ref>

In March 2020, acclaimed funk musician [[Bootsy Collins]] invited EmiSunshine to collaborate with him on the song "Stars" to benefit the [[Recording Academy]]'s MusiCares COVID-19 Relief Fund. Released on June 12, the single and an accompanying music video featured guest appearances by Dr. [[Cornel West]], [[Béla Fleck]], [[Steve Jordan (drummer)]], [[Victor Wooten]], [[Olvido Ruiz]], [[Manou Gallo]], [[Uché]] and others.<ref name="soundslikenashville.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/bootsy-collins-emisunshine-stars-collaboration/|title=Rock and Roll Hall of Famer Bootsy Collins and Country Upstart EmiSunshine Join Forces on 'Stars'|date=June 12, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref> A remixed version of "Stars" later appeared as "Stargate" on Collins' album ''The Power of the One'', which was released on October 23, 2020.<ref name="bassmagazine.com">{{cite web|url=https://bassmagazine.com/artists/bootsy-collins-to-release-new-album-the-power-of-the-one-on-october-23rd|title=Bootsy Collins to Release New Album 'The Power of the One' on October 23rd|date=September 16, 2020|work=Bass Magazine}}</ref>

On March 21 and 22, 2021, EmiSunshine appeared on ''[[American Idol]]'', performing the [[Johnny Cash]] song "I Walk the Line" as a duet with fellow contestant Alex Miller, a 17-year-old singer from Kentucky. Country star [[Luke Bryan]], a judge on the program, gave the pair "kudos" and said that Emi "really carried a lot of that performance."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/now/american-idol-singers-frightening-face-plant-leaves-judges-contestants-crew-in-shock-021848543.html|title=American Idol singer's frightening face-plant leaves judges, contestants, crew in shock|date=March 23, 2021|work=Yahoo! Entertainment}}</ref> Both artists advanced to the "Showstopper" round one week later, but did not continue beyond that.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/emisunshine-american-idol/
|title=EmiSunshine Covers Fellow Folk and Bluegrass Singer at Heart Janis Joplin on 'American Idol'|date=March 31, 2021|work=Wide Open Country}}</ref>

In February 2022, EmiSunshine released her first solo album, ''Diamonds'', receiving mostly positive reviews, with ''No Depression'' describing it as “(filtering) the traditional sounds of roots music through pop.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emisunshine-takes-a-new-musical-direction-on-solo-outing-diamonds/
|title=EmiSunshine takes a new direction on solo outing Diamonds|date=February 1, 2022|work=No Depression}}</ref> ''American Songwriter'' wrote that “''Diamonds'' can be considered an ambitious offering from an artist whose talent and ambition reside well beyond her years.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/review-emisunshine-shares-the-brightness-of-her-being/|title=EmiSunshine shares the brightness of her being|date=April 5, 2022|work=American Songwriter}}</ref>

EmiSunshine's 10th studio album, ''Sideshow'' was released in October 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/new-country-music-released-this-week-oct-6/
|title=18 new country songs and albums released this week|date=October 6, 2023|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> In a review, ''Wide Open Country'' described the album as "another solid example of how to acknowledge the past while pushing folksier music into the future."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/country-music-playlist/
|title=6 New Country Songs You Need to Hear This Week|date=October 6, 2023|work=Wide Open Country}}</ref>

EmiSunshine performs about 150 shows a year across the country. She has performed twice on [[Marty Stuart]]’s Late Night Jam at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] during CMA Music Fest<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/marty-stuarts-hillbilly-answer-to-cma-fest-20140606|title=Marty Stuart's 'Hillbilly' Answer to CMA Fest|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=6 June 2014 }}</ref> and has had 16 performances at the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opry.com/artist/emisunshine|title=EMISUNSHINE|work=Grand Ole Opry|access-date=2015-09-08|archive-date=2017-03-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331205218/http://www.opry.com/artist/emisunshine|url-status=dead}}</ref> She has also appeared on several national television shows, including ''[[Little Big Shots]]'', ''[[Song of the Mountains]]'', ''[[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]'' and ''[[Pickler & Ben]]''.
